chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text: $a)$ A profitability index is calculated by dividing the present value of an investment's future cash flows by the initial cost of the venture, so it's known as the benefit-cost ratio because it's calculated by dividing the present value of benefits by the project's cost. This profitability index calculates the profit that a dollar invested in a project generates.

The project with such a profitability index greater than one has a present value of cash inflows greater than the project's cost, as a consequence, the project is financially viable, a profitability index of less than one, and on the other hand, indicates that the present value of a project's cash inflows is much less than the project's cost, indicating that such project was unprofitable.

$b)$ When both the profitability index as well as the net present value provide equal accept or decline judgments when evaluating an investment project, they are connected, despite the fact that both procedures produce equal accept or decline choices, this only occurs when evaluating separate projects.

In some cases, however, the net present value is favored over the profitability index, it happens when two investments are mutually exclusive. If there were mutually exclusive investments, the net present value and profitability index results diverge because the profitability index, such as the internal rate of return, suffers from such a ranking difficulty under mutually exclusive investments.
